title: Monday, 8th August, 2016
bodyHTML:
11:00 am
PM

Morning

PM

There is some news around

PM

I think

11:01 am
PM

PM

Such as...

PM

PM

PM

That's courtesy of https://twitter.com/katie_martin_fx

PM

In other news....

PM

Actually pretty much all of AV will close down.

11:03 am

Just of the week

PM

Of course, if anything happens we will open up again

PM

But we need some down time to catch up with stuff

11:04 am
undefined
PM

In the meantime

PM

11:04 am
PM

Let's just go to the main movers

Barclays PLC (BARC:LSE): Last: 157.55, up 5.55 (+3.65%), High: 158.20, Low: 155.07, Volume: 20.98m
BE

Exane push, right?

11:05 am
PM

Kinda stand out -- given the banks response to last Thursday

PM

Yeah, Jon Pierce of Exane

PM

Former Credit Suisse analyst -- where he was top of the Extel rankings

11:06 am
PM

Went off to become a school teacher for a while. Now very much back in business at Exane

PM

Exane seem to have been quietly building a very strong research team

BE

The theory here is that Barclays has access to markets again so can buy back its prefs, providing an immediate 10% bump to EPS? Right?

11:07 am
PM

Yeah, that's the key point

PM

I will chuck the first page up and then we can discuss those prefs etc

PM

It's a sector wide note, btw

11:07 am
PM

A difficult cocktail of profit headwinds
First half numbers threw up few surprises with the focus therefore on outlook statements. With the
sector appearing to face a combination of slowing loan growth, lower margins and higher
impairment, our sizeable EPS cuts post the vote to leave the EU look - at this early stage – to be
justified. Clearly share prices are lower than they were, but with a market value of GBP210bn
against potential distributions of GBP25bn over the next three years and an annual attributable
profit of GBP23bn thereafter, the valuation of the sector is still not that compelling.
Revenue pressure a particular concern
The key feature for us was the additional disclosure on structural hedge revenue. The three large
domestic banks have hedge positions of around GBP350bn generating revenues some GBP4.5bn
above rates currently available in the market. That is 25% of this year's core profit. Maturities over
the next three years could therefore provide a 10-15% earnings headwind.

PM

But there is a story at Barclays
Barclays' core PBT was 10% ahead of consensus in H1 2016 thanks to better pre-provision profit.
Furthermore, the group gave comfort on both the capital outlook and access to the EU financial
services market. Taken together, this has reignited our view that the bank could call all of its
expensive preference shares over the next year adding over 10% to core earnings. Attention
should then turn to other expensive capital securities that depress earnings by another 15%. This
will help to offset other sector wide pressures.
Barclays upgraded to Outperform – our favourite large UK bank
With TNAV at 289p, a credible capital plan and a clear mathematical route to improving returns,
Barclays’ shares could re-rate appreciably. We see TSR of 35-40% over one year and upgrade to
Outperform. Other ratings remain as before with HSBC on Neutral (TP 540p), LBG Underperform
(TP 52p), RBS Neutral (TP180p) and Standard Chartered Underperform (TP550p).

PM

Here's the costly paper Pierce reckons Barclays might buy back..

11:08 am
PM

PM

Right click to read

PM

And also these

11:08 am
PM

PM

We have talked about this before and will
not go into detail again but the argument is simple. Barclays has GBP16bn of liabilities
that currently cost the bank over 20% of core profit to service.

BE

Just spinning through the note, which is quite a serious bit of work .....

11:09 am
BE

The Barclays' story is differentiated from other banks in that there is a clear path to
improving returns that do not depend on better market conditions or aggressive cost
cutting. It is a mathematical function of lower funding costs and to some extent lower
accounting related bonus accruals in the IB.

Yet its shares trade at half of current book value. A standout comparison for us is LBG
which trades at an 85% book multiple premium to Barclays. Certainly, LBG justifies a
higher multiple given the simpler, lower risk / higher return business model but the
valuation gap is inconsistent in our view.

BE

Phrased like that, I can see the argument.

BE

Price to book of 0.52 times does look rather wrong.

11:11 am
BE

In terms of the others, note Exane also going for no more HSBC buybacks.

HSBC Holdings PLC (HSBA:LSE): Last: 537.60, up 7.2 (+1.36%), High: 539.80, Low: 535.20, Volume: 17.70m
BE

Which is a point of contention among the sellside. Merrill last week rolled up a potential ~£20bn, though that was mostly the sale of that Chinese bank minority they own.

11:12 am

We [...] believe that the decision to buy back USD2.5bn of stock in 2H16 is unlikely to
be repeated, with this buyback largely reflecting a lack of reinvestment opportunities
post the sale of the group’s Brazil business. We view the main constraint to further
buybacks to be the group’s consolidated capital position, something that is not affected
by the potential repatriation of capital from the US.

11:25 am
BE

Investment view: Meggitt is undoubtedly well positioned to deliver longerterm
growth from its broad civil aerospace businesses (55% of sales)
including attractive recurring aftermarket (AM) revenues. However,
specific programme exposures mean that its cash inflection will lag other
civil companies we cover by 6-12 months (i.e. 2018). In the nearer term, we
see limited upside to earnings with trading headwinds in the energy and
business jets segments and negative mix effects only likely to moderate in
H2. Continuing volatility in the AM and the spectre of a potential IFRS 15
adjustment could also weigh on sentiment. IFRS 15 will limit the ability to
capitalise the cost of giving away parts, potentially leading to a c£300m
(non-cash) write-off and a c10%+ negative rebase to EPS from 2017. The
shares have performed relatively well ytd (+13%) and recovered half the
ground lost after last year’s profit warning. Our new price target of 440p
(from 450p) offers insufficient upside to justify a Buy rating and reflects
updated peer multiples, a higher pension deficit and debt assumptions in
our blended SOTPs and DCF models.

BE

H1 2016 results highlights: Results were in line; 11% sales growth, boosted
by currency and acquisitions, reflected a 2% organic decline due to weaker
military and energy end-markets, as expected. Full-year guidance was
confirmed, underpinned by good order intake (+6%), and the dividend was
raised by 4.3%. A few metrics were slightly less favourable than hoped, e.g.
civil AM growth of just +2% in Q2, net debt/EBITDA of 2.6x (above target
range of 1.5-2.5x), and a free cash outflow of £33m (due to aerospace
inventory build and 2015 contract flows).

BE

Financials: Group revenue was £883m (+11%, -2% organic), adjusted EBIT
£163m (+2%, -9% organic), adjusted EPS 15.4p (+1% yoy), and DPS 4.8p (+4%
yoy). Growth by sector: Civil OE +4% (Q2: +3%), civil AM +4% (Q2: +2%),
military -5% (Q2: -11%), energy -19% (Q2: -23%); and FCF -£33m (versus
£38m in H1 2015).
● Guidance: Confirmed as low single-digit percentage organic growth. By
sector, expectations are for civil AM and civil OE to increase by low to midsingle
digit percentage, military growth of low single-digit percentage, and
energy declines to moderate. Acquisitions and FX will add c10% and c8%
respectively (at current rates).
● Forecast changes (EPS +1.5%): We increase our revenue forecasts by 1-3%
mainly reflecting FX. This more than offsets lower margin assumptions
(mix) which nets to a 1% increase to 2016 EPS, and 1.5% increase thereafter.
● Valuation: Meggitt trades on a 2016/17/18 P/E of 13.1x, 12.3x and 11.5x, and
a 2016/17/18 EV/EBITDA of 10.9x, 9.6x and 8.9x.

11:25 am
PM

Airbus has had a corruption stink somewhere around it, for how long? It's at least 12 years since the Economist did a hugely detailed number on the matter.

Yep, the whole industry has issues with intermediaries and payments taking circuitous routes. Notably for Rolls, of course.

related to irregularities concerning third-party consultants not correctly disclosed in applications to the European Export Credit Agencies.

BE

Applications to the UK ECA were frozen as of April 2016, but Airbus has stated it hopes business will resume in 4Q16. A formal investigation was inevitable in the current environment, in our view.

11:28 am
BE

Details: In 1H16, Airbus invested €587m in aircraft customer financing, up from €63m
in 1H15. In FY15, Airbus invested €150m. In FY14, there was an inflow of €108m. At end
1H16, there was no net customer financing exposure, after deducting collateral (aircraft)
and provisions. The major risk is to FCF guidance for FY16. Airbus states it has agreed a way forward with the UK ECA to restore financing in 4Q16.

BE

Redburn's Stephen Swanton turns buyer this morning, though. Which makes me think I'm probably wrong.

BE

There's only so much of Redburn stuff we can quote without really irritating someone, so I'll try and cut this into manageable bits.

11:38 am
BE

As potential deals for Melrose go, buying Nortek makes complete
sense. We doubt if Nortek will experience much growth under
Melrose but the margin opportunity is glaring and there are
acquirers for Nortek's businesses when Melrose is ready to sell.
When Nortek’s restructuring is done, Melrose will be on 11x PE.
This leaves 70% upside over 2-3 years. We upgrade to Buy.

BE

The danger with writing this note prior to now is an interloper could have intervened
in Melrose’s purchase of Nortek. The call felt binary. If such an event had happened
Melrose’s shares would have tumbled 30-40% to where they started. On early Sunday
morning (7 Aug) the ‘window shop’ period for others to bid for Nortek expired.

The merits of the Nortek deal are so straight forward we are surprised a rival bid did
not emerge. However, Nortek is best restructured and then broken up. That is how it
will end up under Melrose. The value creation from this is seen in in Fig 1 – Melrose’s
new starting margins of 8% will end up at 14-15% in three years. We have based our
valuation metrics on a TERP of 140p following the £1.7bn rights issue.

PM

You are right on one thing here Bryce -- margin opportunity obv = job cuts

11:40 am
BE

Well, yes. I'm thinking it must be that Nortek was really, really slack with costs (while under public ownership!) ..... And Melrose was the only company to notice this ... in spite of every company within and outwith its sector taking a look over recent years.

BE

I'm a bit lost as to how that could've happened. But apparently it did. So .....

BE

If Nortek can be restructured and improved such that it generates 16% margins then it
will leave the Melrose group margin at 14.9% in 2019. Even without
much sales growth at Nortek, Melrose’s share price could be worth 246p under this
margin progression .....

BE

BE

11:45 am
BE

Trading update. YouGov reports that trading for the year to July was 'slightly ahead' of expectations. It indicates that revenue growth continued in double digits, following +13% in FY15 and +15% in 1H16. Net cash finished the period at £15.0m, ahead of our prior forecast of £13.6m.
Trading by discipline. At its interims, YouGov reported that it continued to enjoy very strong momentum in its Data Products (led by BrandIndex) and Data Services (principally Omnibus), with a strong start made to the new Profiles data product, which has continued throughout the second half.
Trading by geography. YouGov generated good growth across its geographies in H1, notably the UK, US, Middle East and the newer markets in France and Asia Pacific. At the pre-close the group highlights the US and Middle East, where organic growth has been amplified by FX tailwinds.
FX. In 2015, YouGov generated 70% of revenues and approximately half of profits outside the UK and given the improved operational performance as the UK model is rolled out internationally, we expect this proportion to increase over time.
Forecasts. We raise our forecasts by +7% to £11.7m/8.5p (was £10.9m/8.0p) for July 2016 and +6% to £13.3m/9.6p (was £12.5m/9.2p) for 2017.
Recommendation. We roll forward our valuation to 2017 and flow through our increased forecasts which increases our target price to 218p (was 177p) though after the strong run this year we now rate the shares as an Add (was Buy).

BE

Stop buying. Start adding.

undefined
11:46 am
BE

InterContinental was mentioned earlier.

InterContinental Hotels Group PLC (IHG:LSE): Last: 3,213, up 39 (+1.23%), High: 3,247, Low: 3,174, Volume: 268.43k
BE

On the back of a Sunday Times story, that looked rather underpowered and was later denied in the present tense.

11:47 am
BE

Original here: http://www.thetime...-9f89-1792df6a9825

BE

Denial here: http://www.bloombe...r-intercontinental

BE

We've talked in the past about IHG being a target for Anbang, and suggested it was a long shot

11:49 am
BE

As Anbang seems to want real estate rather than franchises

BE

As per its Starwood move

BE

(@nichoman: yes, it is. Though it's present tense, as I say.)

11:51 am
BE

Few bits of sellside around this morning, rechurning the arguments about IHG ......

BE

Morgan Stanley, for instance .....

BE

IHG continues to be dogged by M&A speculation, the latest that
Chinese insurer Anbang, which lost out on Starwood, is mulling an
offer. Further consolidation in the hotel industry looks likely, and
trade buyers have the advantage of synergies, so pressure may build
on IHG to consider alternatives.

11:52 am
BE

... written pre denial, I think. Jamie Rollo putting in the shift on Sunday morning.

BE

We think IHG is an attractive company. It operates in a growth industry, is
the third largest hotelier globally by rooms (market leader is the USA and
China), owns the world's largest hotel brand Holiday Inn, generates 97% of
profit from fees from franchising and managing third-party hotels (so high
margin and low capex needs), has a self-funding business model with most
brand/technology costs funded by third party hotels, and has a pipeline of
rooms equivalent to 30% rooms growth when they open. Although the hotel
cycle seems to be coming to an end after 7 years of growth, with most markets
on peak occupancies and seeing slowing RevPAR, IHG has a relatively resilient
business model, with 1% of RevPAR just 2% to EBIT, and minimal income from
more cyclical incentive fees or owned/leased hotels.

BE

Consolidation is an ongoing theme in the hotel industry. Marriott has
recently acquired Starwood for $13.6bn, and Accor has recently acquired
Fairmont Raffles for $2.8bn. Consolidation would bring significant cost and
revenue synergies as we discussed here , though as Anbang does not have a
large existing hotel operation these would presumably not be open to it (c. 20
hotels vs 5,000 at IHG). According to Marriott's S-4 filing, over 30 potential
parties either contacted Starwood or were contacted by Starwood's financial
advisors during its sale process, with 10 expressing interest in a potential sale
or merger, and 7 signing confidentiality agreements. There was a healthy mix
between domestic US companies as well as foreign companies. IHG reportedly
made contact with both Starwood and Fairmont, though in July 2015 it put out
a statement saying it was not in talks with Starwood with a view to a
combination of the businesses. In November 2015, following market
speculation it was exploring strategic options, IHG stated that it was not
considering a potential sale or merger of the company. In 2014, IHG was
reported to have rejected an offer from Wyndham (neither company
commented), and was then subject to an activist campaign by hedge fund
Marcato, which agitated unsuccessfully for a sale (it has also been subject to
activists such as Trion and the Barclay Brothers in the past).

11:52 am
BE

IHG trades on a 2017e EV/EBITDA of 11.2x and P/E of 17.6x. These are
small discounts to asset-light peers Marriott on 11.3x (including Starwood)
and Choice on 12.3x. Marriott paid 12.3x forward EBITDA for Starwood (ex the
Vistana time share spin out), but it was an all-share offer so selling
shareholders shared in the upside from synergies. Accor paid 20x for FRHI, but
the company operated in the luxury space so is perhaps less comparable.

BE

Loads more there, largely about Anbang's strategy, but that feels a little redundant now post denial.

BE

Credit Suisse too, if you want it.

11:53 am
BE

Key thoughts on a deal: 1) Scarcity value - as discussed in European M&A
– When East meets West - we believe IHG is an attractive asset - high
returns (2015 ROIC 30%), simple business model (97% of 2016E EBIT from
managed/franchised hotels), strong cash generation (89% of 2016-18E net
income to FCF) and a straightforward ownership structure (100% free float).
2) Anbang bid $14bn for Starwood in a full financed deal. 3) Bears believe
IHG was unlikely to see interest from Chinese bidders due to a lack of real
estate, whilst we believe the lack of sell-side Buy recommendations (just
12% according to Bloomberg) reflects a perceived lack of catalysts (US cycle
well progressed; major real estate disposals completed). 4) Following
Starwood and Marriott's planned merger, we believe further consolidation is
likely in a fragmented industry with very few truly global and scale players.
The potential Accor interest from Jin Jiang (owns 12%) and now Anbang in
IHG would not likely generate material synergies but an appetite for global
diversification and a low cost of capital help underpin Chinese interest.

BE

Thoughts on valuation: Our 3500p TP (10% potential upside) is the
average of a SOTP and DCF (latter 3975p – 32% upside potential). The
£7bn mentioned in the article is 12% above current levels but we note IHG
has traded c25x PE on previous occasions when bid speculation has been
high (incl 2007 when Blackstone bought Hilton) - which if applied to our
2017E EPS would yield a value of 4360p, implying 37% potential upside.
